description.narrative: Standards and standardisation can be used as a tool for supporting a more sustainabledevelopment and to promote trade opportunities. The aim of this contribution was to improve stakeholder driven standardisation processes within the ECOWAS region, leading to increased use and harmonisation of ECOWAS and ARSO standards. Enhanced knowledge and experience on regional and international standard setting processes among national standardization bodies (NSB) and other involved stakeholders in the ECOWAS region, leading to enhanced capacity and involvement of ECOWAS stakeholders in both ARSO- and ISO standard setting processes as well as more regional collaboration on standards.

Den svenska standardiseringsorganisationen SIS har ansökt till den regionala sektionen vid Ambassaden i Addis Ababa om 7 050 000 SEK under perioden augusti 2015 till augusti 2017 för ett projekt som syftar till kapacitetsuppbyggnad i internationell standardisering i ECOWAS-regionen genom ett gemensam insats av den Afrikanska regionala standardiseringsorganisationen (ARSO), den regionala ekonomiska gemenskapen för västra Afrika (ECOWAS) och den svenska standardiseringsorganisationen (SIS).
Genom projektet ska ECOWAS-regionens inflytande över och användande av ISO- och ARSO-systemen öka. Detta ska uppnås genom att en eller två pågående standardiseringsprocesser i ISO väljs ut som fallstudier runt vilka kapacitetsuppbyggnad sker. Arbetet med dessa standardiseringsprocesser i ISO kommer även att länkas till liknande pågående arbete i någon av ARSO:s 13 s.k. Tekniska Harmoniseringskommitteer liksom till pågående harmoniseringsarbete av standarder inom ECOWAS. Fallstudierna ska ligga till grund för att identifiera arbete med att involvera relevanta intressenter (främst från den privata sektorn, universitet och högskolor, frivilligorganisationer, statliga organ samt standardiseringsorgan), ökat engagemang av ECOWAS-länderna i ISO samt synkronisering av de nationella, regionala och internationella standardiseringsagendorna.
Projektet är kort och föreslås endast löpa under ca en två-årsperiod för att testa samarbetet mellan de tre ansvariga organisationerna och mellan dem och regionen. Tidigare erfarenhet har dock visat att även ett korttidsprojekt som involverar en hel region kan vara avgörande genom att leda till en ökad medvetenhet som i sin tur leder till positiva förändringar, både för länder som redan är fullvärdiga ISO-medlemmar och för de som inte är det.
Projektets totala budget är 7 050 000 SEK och parterna har begärt att den regionala sektionen vid Ambassaden i Addis Ababa står för helheten. ECOWAS Kommission och ARSO Sekretariatet, liksom de nationella standardinseringsorganen i regionen kommer dock att bidra med medarbetares tid och engagemang.

The Swedish Standardization Body SIS has applied to the Regional Section of the Swedish Embassy in Addis Ababa for funding of 7 050 000 SEK to carry out a project aimed at capacity building in international standardisation in the ECOWAS Region through a joint effort by the African Regional Organisation for Standardisation, ARSO, the Economic Community of West African States, ECOWAS and the Swedish Standarisation Institute, SIS. The project shall enhance the ECOWAS region's influence and use of the ISO and ARSO systems.
This will be achieved through the selection of one or two ISO standardisation processes as case studies around which the capacity strengthening will be built. Work on the standardisation processes in ISO will also be linked up with one of the 13 ARSO Technical Harmonisation Committees (THC) that relates to the specific ISO process/es, as well as with the harmonisation work on standards within ECOWAS. The cases will also serve as basis for identifying action on issues such as involvement of stakeholders (primarily the private sector, academia, NGOs, governmental agencies and national standardisation bodies), further involvement in the ISO system, as well as synchronizing national, regional and international standardisation agendas.
It is a short-term project proposed to run over a two-year period to test the collaboration between the three responsible organisations and between them and the region. However, previous experience has shown that by involving a region jointly in this area, even shorter-term actions can prove crucial in increasing awareness and that the exposure can lead to tangible, positive changes both for those countries that are already involved in international standardisation and those that are not.
The intervention’s total budget is 7 050 000 million SEK, and SIS has requested the Regional Section of the Swedish Embassy in Addis Ababa to cover the totality. In addition, the ECOWAS Commission and the ARSO Secretariat as well ECOWAS Member States will contribute with staff time and engagement.

description.narrative: The proposed project aimed to contribute to vital and sustainable, local and regional, standardization processes with broad involvement from the private and public sectors, as well as from civil society, in order to build the capacity necessary to influence the content of international standards. The Swedish Standards Institute (SIS), the ECOWAS Commission, and the African Organization for Standardisation (ARSO) picked two ongoing standardization-setting processes of the International Organization for Standardization (ISO) as case studies. The was to provide the National Standardization Bodies (NSBs) of the ECOWAS countries with knowledge about standard processes, about standard-setting in general, and about how to influence ISO- and ARSO-standards from a national and regional perspective. The project was managed in close collaboration with the ECOWAS Secretariat in Abuja, Nigeria and ARSO, African Regional Standards Organization, in Nairobi, Kenya. A key to success of the project was close collaboration between SIS, ECOWAS and ARSO and two coordinators were hired to be based on ECOWAS- and ARSO- Secretariats respectively to strengthen the project and increase ownership. The project commenced with an inception phase of six months (June-November 2016) and continued with a 13 months implementation phase. Despite the short implementation period, the project has contributed to influencing and highlighting the need for the NSBs in the ECOWAS region to increase their active participation in standard development. By and large, the project has made a positive contribution to the ECOWAS region in terms of building capacity for national and regional standardisation. For example through contributing to strengthening individuals and organizations capacity in standard development; facilitating and support regional harmonization of standards in the region; and support to the countries through ARSO/ISO sponsorship to participate in ARSO/ISO meetings allowing the region to influence the standardisation processes and affect the standards per se. Some examples of activities are that two regional capacity building activities, sponsorships to five different ARSO/ISO meetings (1 ISO and 4 ARSO) and three online sessions have been conducted during the project lifetime. The two selected standardisation processes as case studies to increase the capacity on how to engage and contribute to standard development were ISO/TC 34 (ARSO THC 02) on Food and Agriculture and ISO/TC 59(ARSO THC 03) on Building and Construction. More than 100 individuals have participated in workshops and trainings. The project led to increased number of approved ARSO/ISO sponsored delegates as well as number of different ARSO/ISO meetings attended. Moreover, increased participation by experts /stakeholders representing private/public sectors in the ECOWAS region was a result of this project.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
